channel.title: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file
channel.description: Is there any way to delete a specific line (or section of text) from a txt file, or any type of file with java?

item.title: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.source: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file

item.title: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

the reason you wouldnt flush after every operation is because you have to wait for the data to be written to disk

Read full topic
item.source: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file

item.title: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Speed and memory aren’t the issue. The only thing flush does is clear out the (small) caches in the network stack. They aren’t deallocated and they’re small anyway.

The issue is when the server wants the last few bytes of the file or messages your sending. For example with a script reading lines from across the network it might skip the last few as they are held in the client’s cache and not actually sent to the server. By using flush you make sure the server gets all the information you wrote.

Read full topic
item.source: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file

item.title: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

supamagier:

What’s that good for? Speed?

It makes sure everything you’ve told it to write gets written, then frees up memory by deleting the data in the byte array buffer for the stream.
It’s just a good practise kind of thing, as it makes sure everything has finished up and the memory is deallocated.
So yeah, speed and consistency.

Read full topic

item.title: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

It makes sure everything in the buffer has been written then clears the buffer of all data.

item.source: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file

item.title: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

i think that depends on the situation, like in this on, its probably better to move that flush outside the loop

String line;
while((line = someBufferedReader.readLine()) != null) {
    if(line.equals("line to be deleted")) {
        // Leave blank so it's not written.
    } else {
        someBufferedWriter.write(line);
    }
}
someBufferedWriter.flush();

but for other stuff, it is good, like if you’re writing to a socket outputstream

sockOut.write(someBytes); //wait for reply from server

you will probably be waiting forever, because the bytes might not have been sent

sockOut.write(someBytes); [b]sockOut.flush()[/b] //wait for reply from server

Read full topic
item.source: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file

item.title: Any way to delete from a txt file? Or any file
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:4, topic:204179”]String line;
while((line = someBufferedReader.readLine()) != null) {
if(line.equals(“line to be deleted”)) {
// Leave blank so it’s not written.
} else {
someBufferedWriter.write(line);
SomeBufferedWriter.flush();
}
}[/quote]
Flushing after every write is very bad practice.

Read full topic
